awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: A reactor (electrolyzer) that converts carbon dioxide to fuels and chemicals using renewable sources of energy
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project lies in the electrochemical conversion of carbon dioxide (CO2) to valuable fuels.  This technology plays a role in the carbon capture and utilization process that has the potential to significantly reduce CO2 emissions. Production of carbon neutral fuels and chemicals from CO2 using renewable electricity is a commercially viable pathway to offset the carbon footprint. The proposed efficient solution supports profitable production of carbon neutral fuels and chemicals. When scaled, this technology may impact a wide spectrum of areas that currently depend on fuels and chemicals produced using traditional methods ranging from aviation fuels to pharmaceuticals.

This I-Corps project focuses on carbon utilization and production of clean fuels and chemicals to help mitigate climate change. The proposed method employs electrochemical conversion of CO2 using renewable electricity and water, generation of synthesis gas (syngas), and further conversion of syngas in the Fischer-Tropsch process to produce a wide variety of chemicals. This technology represents a new class of catalysts with high energy efficiency and selectivity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
FixingCO2?s breakthrough patented technology converts CO2 into fuels and chemicals. Our CO2 electrolyzer uses water and electricity to convert CO2 into Carbon Monoxide, a valuable commodity chemical. In addition, mixed with hydrogen, CO creates syngas that can be used to make clean fuels and chemicals. This highly efficient process provides a commercially viable solution for the zero-emissions economy.

 

During the I-COPRs program, the FixingCO2 team conducted customer discovery work to search for commercialization opportunities in key industrial segments: 

  • Chemical industry
  • Clean steel production
  • Sustainable aviation fuel production

 

The team conducted 114 interviews throughout the course of the program, and continued the customer discovery work. Key learnings about the CO2 utilisation ecosystem were uncovered including potential customer segments, distribution channels, value propositions for the innovative CO2 utilisation technology. Specifically,

  • The chemical industry customer segment was found to be hard for commercialization due to challenges with gas distribution and technology cost
  • A customer segment  in clean steel production was identified and interest confirmed. In order to commercialize in this space, the technology needs further scaling
  • Sustainable aviation fuels segment was studied, interest confirmed, also requires scale-up of the technology
  • Potential scale-up pathway was investigated based on hydrogen electrolyzer industry standards

 

 

As a result of the work in the I-COPRs program, the team identified challenges and barriers for technology adoption, clarified the scale-up pathway using a similar hydrogen electrolyzer technology and estimated necessary resources to enable technology scale-up. We?ve continued our work by submitting applications for government grants such as AFWERX, participating in the Berkeley Skydeck incubator, and continuing the technical development of the electrolyzer prototype.

 


Last Modified: 02/26/2022
Modified by: Clifford P Kubiak
